Graphical abstract Mn-promoted nickel-based catalysts were explored for the direct hydrogenation of microalgae (Chlorococcum sp.) containing 49.6% of carbohydrates in water. With this catalyst at 250 °C for 3.0 h, microalgae was completely decomposed, where the conversion of microalgae to liquid products (CTL) and the total yield of polyols reached 66.9%, and 53.6%, respectively. Among polyols, the total yield of 1,2-propanediol and ethylene glycol were 41.7%. XRD, XPS and TEM-EDX characterizations showed that 5% of Mn addition, 350 °C of reduction temperature and the co-precipitation synthesis ensured the excellent dispersion of the Ni catalyst with small particle sizes. The Mn promoter was found to stabilize the catalyst structure by preventing the Ni particles from aggregation and to effectively promote retro-aldol and dehydroxylation reaction due to the increasing number of Lewis acid sites. Meanwhile, the hydrogenation pathways over nickel-based catalysts were proposed. Keywords Microalgae Hydrogenation 1,2-Propanediol Ethylene glycol Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalyst 1 Introduction The manufacture of bulk chemicals, such as 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) and ethylene glycol (EG), from biomass instead of from fossil resources can contribute significantly to a sustainable and environment-friendly chemical industry [1–5]. Due to the shift towards renewable feedstocks from fossil resources, new catalytic processes are being developed, where the utilization of heterogeneous catalysts is preferred [6–9]. Biomass hydrogenation is a promising route for chemical production from biomass due to its economic benefit and environmental sustainability. Nickel-based catalysts are preferred for biomass hydrogenation due to their much lower cost and better availability compared to noble metal-based catalysts. In addition, nickel-based catalysts also have the proper reduction capability for biomass hydrogenation, as catalysts with too strong reduction capability will transform biomass into gaseous products and catalysts with too weak reduction capability will yield mostly C6 alcohols [10–12]. Great efforts have been taken to develop selective catalysts for biomass hydrogenation, and representative catalysts are Ni-W2C/AC developed by Zhang’s group [13–15]. They developed an environment-friendly approach for the catalytic degradation of cellulose into glycols, and the yield of EG reached 61% attributed to the synergism between nickel and W2C. However, the total yield for the conversion of raw biomass feedstock, such as corn stalk, to EG and 1,2-PDO was limited to 48% in addition to the fact that the feedstock had to be pretreated with organic solvents and/or alkali solutions. Mu’s group further examined the performance of nickel-based catalysts supported by Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2, activated carbon, ZnO, ZrO2 and MgO, and the catalyst support was found to play an important role in the product distribution and the best performance was obtained using 20% Ni/ZnO as the catalyst with complete cellulose conversion and a total glycol yield of 70.4% [16]. In the above-mentioned reports, pure substrates, such as cellulose, glucose, sorbitols, xylitols, were usually chosen to investigate the catalytic performance and the reaction mechanism [17–21]. When using corn stalk, miscanthus and jerusalem artichole tubers as the reactants, pretreatment and purification were required to enhance the carbohydrate content and to improve the catalytic efficiency [22–24]. Miscanthus was used for producing EG with a yield of 35.5% over a binary catalyst consisting of commercial tungstic acid and Raney Ni. The formation of organic acids and unsaturated compounds was found to poison the Raney Ni catalyst leading to limited EG yield [22]. Ni-W2C/AC catalysts were found to convert corn stalk to EG and 1,2-PDO with an overall yield of 48.0% [24]. Thus, the catalyst must be sufficiently robust for efficient conversion of raw biomass feedstocks in aqueous medium. In our previous work, we developed a process for the direct hydrogenation of microalgae using the Ni-MgO-ZnO catalyst, and the total yield of the main products, including 1,2-PDO, EG and other alcohols, were 41.5%, among which the combined yield of 1,2-PDO and EG were 33.2% [25]. Thus, the yield remained limited partly due to the poisonous effect of the impurities in microalgae to the Ni-based catalysts, so catalysts with higher reactivity and tolerance to these impurities are to be developed. Promotion of metal catalysts with metal oxides is an effective method to improve the catalytic activity in hydrogenation reactions [26–34]. For the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS), metal oxide promoters were found to significantly affect the catalyst texture and porosity, leading to enhanced dispersion of the active metals as well as their reducibility [31]. Morales et al prepared Mn-promoted Co/TiO2 catalysts, and found that a small amount of Mn promoter could substantially improve the catalytic performance in the FTS reaction by enhancing the dispersion of the active metal [32]. With the Ni-CaO/C catalysts, the combined selectivity of xylitol and polyols reached 69.5% at 200 °C, 4.0 MPa H2. The presence of solid bases rendered the Ni catalysts noticeably more resistant to leaching and sintering, leading to much improved catalytic stability in xylitol hydrogenolysis [20]. Deng and Liu investigated cellulose hydrogenation into polyols over SnOx-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts and the selectivity of hexitols reached 82.7% with a Sn/Pt ratio of 0.5, although the conversion was only 17.1% [33]. Ni-Cu/ZnO catalysts were prepared for the hydrogenolysis of cellulose into 1,2-alkanediols with a selectivity of 72.5% under 245 °C, 4.0 MPa H2. Synergism between the Ni and Cu species led to the efficient formation of 1,2-alkanediols via dehydroxylation and CC bond breaking [34]. In this work, we used Mn as additive promoter to substantially improve the catalytic performance of Ni-ZnO catalysts for one-pot hydrogenation of microalgae in hot water. The catalysts were thoroughly characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) to elucidate the role of the Mn promoter on the structure of the catalyst. Influence of various catalyst preparation parameters, such as the amount of Mn, the reduction temperature, and the metal loading method on the performance of the catalysts, was systematically investigated. In addition, the catalytic mechanism and the effect of the Mn promoter on the reaction pathway were further elucidated by using several reaction intermediates as model substrates in further hydrogenation experiments under the same reaction conditions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The microalgae (Chlorococcum sp.) were cultivated with the same method as reported in our previous work [25]. All the other regents and chemicals were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, and used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalysts (MNZ) were prepared by co-precipitation. Briefly, the metal salts (nickel, zinc and manganese nitrates) were mixed in aqueous solution with a fixed molar ratio. The solution of Na2CO3 was then added dropwise into the above mixture under vigorous stirring at 70 °C at the pH value of 7.0. The resultant mixture was aged under continuous stirring at the same temperature for 3–4 h, followed by vacuum filtration. Olivine powder was collected after being dried at 80 °C overnight and ground by mortar. The collected powder was calcined in the air by increasing the temperature at the rate of 5 °C/min–400 °C and then kept at this temperature for 5 h. This was followed by reduction under H2 by further increasing the temperature at the rate of 5 °C/min to some temperature and kept at that temperature for 10 h. The catalysts were passivated in a flow of 0.5% O2/N2 for 3.0 h at room temperature before exposure to the air in case of being burned. Other metal-doped catalysts (such as W-promoted Ni-ZnO, Ce-promoted Ni-ZnO, and Zr-promoted Ni-ZnO) were prepared with the same method by changing the precursors and the molar ratios of metal nitrates. Catalysts prepared with the impregnation method were synthesized in the traditional approach [35]. For MNZ-1 catalysts, Ni was loaded onto the support Mn-doped ZnO by incipient wetness impregnation using as nickel nitrate as the precursor. The Mn-doped ZnO support was synthesized by the co-precipitation method the same as MNZ preparation without nickel nitrates addition. MNZ-2 was prepared by loading nickel onto the mixture of commercial ZnO and MnO by the impregnation method. The calcination and reduction procedure for MNZ-1 and MNZ-2 was identical to that of MNZ. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-Ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were conducted on a Rigaku Ultima IVX-Ray diffractometer with CuK α radiation in the 2θ range from 20° to 80° at a scan rate of 5°/min. The crystallite sizes (D) of nickel species in the catalysts was evaluated by the Scherrer equation, assuming negligible contribution from strain and instrumental broadening to reflection widths, D = kλ/βLcosθ, where k is a dimensionless shape factor with a typical value of about 0.89, λ is the wavelength of the radiation (λCu = 1.54178 Å), βL is the full width at half-maximum, and θ is the diffraction angle for Ni (111), which is the main plain of nickel species [36,37]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on Thermo Scientific K-Alpha with AlKα radiation. The binding energy (BE) of C1s core level (284.8 eV) was used as the reference. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) including high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX) studies were conducted on a JEM-2100F field emission electron microscope at an operating voltage of 200 kV, equipped with a Gatan 832 CCD camera. Prior to the characterization, the samples were dispersed into ethanol solution with ultrasonic treatment for 30 min and then dropped onto a carbon film on copper grid. H2-TPR and NH3-TPD were both conducted on an Auto Chem. II2920 equipment (Mircromeritics, USA). For H2-TPR, 100 mg of sample was placed into a U-shaped quartz tube and pretreated in Ar at 350 °C for 30 min and then cooled to 5 °C. A 10 vol% H2-Ar gas mixture was then applied and the water vapor was condensed with isopropanol-liquid nitrogen slurry. The data were recorded from 50 °C to 850 °C with a ramping rate of 5 °C/min, and simultaneously monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Pyridine-adsorption FTIR (Py-IR) spectra were recorded by a VERTEX70 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrophotometer, equipped with a deuterium triglycine sulphate (DTGS) detector. Typically, about 20 mg of sample was pressed into a self-supporting water of 2 cm in diameter and degassed at 300 °C in vacuum for 1.0 h before exposed to the pyridine vapor and cooled down to 30 °C. The Py-IR spectra were recorded at 200 °C and 350 °C after evacuating for 30 min to remove the physidorbed pyridine [38]. The amounts of Lewis-acid sites and Brønsted-acid sites were determined from the integrated area of the adsorption bands at ca. 1548 and 1442 cm−1, respectively. The extinction coefficients from Emeis’ work [39] were employed. Elemental analysis of the feedstock was performed on a Thermo Scientific Flash 2000 with a CHNS analyzer. The total organic carbon (TOC) and total nitrogen (TN) in the liquid products were obtained with a Shimadzu TOC-L. 2.4 Catalytic experiments and product analysis Direct conversion of microalgae was carried out in a stainless steel autoclave (Parr, 50 mL) with an initial H2 pressure of 6 MPa at 230–250 °C for 180 min. Briefly, 0.25 g of microalgae (1.0 wt.%) and 0.15 g of catalyst were added into 25 mL of deionized water. The mixture was then poured into the autoclave and stirred at a speed of 600 rpm. The reactor was heated to the target temperature and kept for 180 min. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled naturally, and the liquid solution was separated by centrifuging the mixture from the reaction. The solid catalyst was collected and washed with deionized water for three times, followed by drying overnight at 80 °C. Prior to further analysis, the collected liquid solution was filtered through filters with pore size of 0.22 μm. Qualitative and quantitative analyses of the products in the resultant solution were conducted with gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS, Agilent 5975/6890N, HP-INNOWax column: 30 m × 0.25 mm; film thickness, 0.25 μm) with a flame ionization detector (FID) and high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Shimadzu LC-20CE, Aminex HPX-87H ion exclusion column: 300 mm × 7.8 mm) with a differential refraction detector (RID-10 A). The conversion of microalgae to liquid products (CTL) was calculated from the TOC data by: CTL = (moles of carbon in the resultant liquid determined by TOC)/(moles of carbon in microalgae determined by the CHNS analyzer) × 100%. The yield of a specific polyol was determined from the carbon via the equations: Yield of the polyol = (moles of carbon in the polyol determined)/(mole of carbon in the carbohydrate components of microalgae) × 100%. Due to the excess hydrogen present in the tail gas, the amount of the gaseous products was very difficult to quantify, which was only qualitatively analyzed by GC. Nevertheless, the total amount of the gaseous products was estimated from the difference between the total amount of carbon in microalgae and that in the liquid and solid products. All the primary experimental data were repeated three times and the relative error bar was no more than 5%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Screening of promoters for Ni-based catalysts The microalgae (Chlorococcum sp.) used as the feedstock contains 49.6% of carbohydrates, 32.6% of lipids and 11.9% of proteins (Table S1). The complex composition of microalgae demands the catalysts to possess high tolerance to impurities, especially to lipids and proteins, which are usually detrimental to the catalysts. In the catalytic hydrogenation process, about 5–10% of the carbon in microalgae was estimated to be converted into gaseous products, such as CH4, CO2 and CO, via deep CC cracking of the carbon content in microalgae. The solid products with carbon and hydrogen contents of 74% and 12%, respectively, were mostly precipitated carbon from lipids released from the hydrothermal process. The solid products accounted for 25%–35% of all the products. TN analysis of the liquid products shows that the total nitrogen in the liquid products is almost identical to the total amount of nitrogen in microalgae, suggesting that proteins in the microalgae were hydrolyzed and released into the liquid products. Thus, more than half of the solid carbon in the raw materials was turned into liquid products, where alkanediols (including 1,2-PDO, EG) derived from carbohydrates in the microalgae are the main products (Fig. S1). The other liquid products include methanol, acetic acid, which are derived from the deep CC cleavage of carbohydrates and proteins in microalgae, and their amounts are too limited to be quantified. Nickel-based catalysts were reported to have good performance for biomass hydrogenation to sugar alcohols [40–42]. Some metal promoters could enhance the catalytic activity when introduced to the hydrogenation catalyst [27]. We previously showed that catalysts doped with Mg had favorable catalytic activity for microalgae hydrogenation, with the overall yield of 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) and ethylene glycol (EG) reaching up to 33.3% [25]. Based on that work, catalysts with W, Zr, Ce, Mn, and Mg promoters were prepared and investigated in this work (Table 1 ). With these promoted catalysts, the microalgae was completely converted, and 1,2-PDO, EG, glycerol and 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BDO) were found to be the main liquid products. For W-promoted catalysts (W/Ni/ZnO), CTL reached 46.2% with the total yield of the polyols of 34.9% (15.3% of 1,2-PDO, 8.5% of EG, 7.6% of glycerol and 3.5% of 1,2-BDO). The total yields of the polyols were 38.2% and 41.1% for the Zr/Ni/ZnO and Mg/Ni/ZnO catalysts, respectively. Thus, the Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO (Mn/Ni/ZnO) catalyst exhibited the best performance with an overall yield of polyols of 53.6% and the CTL of 66.9%. In our previous study [25], the addition of Mg changed the texture of the catalyst and increased nickel dispersion on the support. Compared with the Mg/Ni/ZnO catalyst, the catalytic efficiency of the Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalyst is higher by 30.5%. Although Mn has been used as a promoter for cobalt-based catalysts in Fisher-Tropsch synthesis [34], promotion of Ni-based catalysts by Mn especially for biomass hydrogenation has not been reported to our knowledge. 3.2 Properties of Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalysts XRD patterns of our catalysts with different amounts of Mn, reduced at different temperatures and synthesized by different methods are shown in Fig. 1 . From Fig. 1a, as the amount of Mn increases, peaks at 2θ = 41.5–42.0°, which are assigned to MnO (JCPDS data No. 07-2030), become stronger and sharper, indicating the formation of crystalline manganic oxide. Notably, catalysts with the Mn promoter below 5% have no diffraction peaks from MnO, suggesting the high dispersion of MnO in these samples. Peak width of Ni varies the amount of Mn, which reflects the crystal size of Ni on the support. Through the Scherrer Equation, Ni crystal sizes were calculated as 9.1 nm for 1%Mn/Ni/ZnO, 8.5 nm for 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO, 10.2 nm for 10%Mn/Ni/ZnO, 10.8 nm for 15%Mn/Ni/ZnO and 13.1 nm for 20%Mn/Ni/ZnO. In addition, the peak for Ni in 20%Mn/Ni/ZnO at 2θ = 43.6° was shifted to the left, which resulted from the presence of Mn species in the crystal lattice of Ni leading to changes in the cell parameters [43]. Fig. 1b compares XRD profiles of 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO with those of Ni/ZnO and Ni/MnOx, where the amount of Ni was fixed and the amount of Mn was maximized and minimized, respectively. The broader diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.3° for the 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalyst indicates the presence of smaller crystal sizes of Ni than those found for Ni/MnOx and Ni/ZnO. Meanwhile, the sharp diffraction peaks at 2θ = 35.0° and 40.6° suggested the presence of well-grown MnO crystals in Ni/MnOx, while they were not observed in the 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO sample. As shown in Fig. 1c, for 5%Mn-doped Ni-based catalysts, the reduction temperature can also affect the nickel crystal size. Ni crystal sizes were calculated from the Scherrer equation as 4.0 nm, 7.6 nm, 8.5 nm and 13.2 nm for 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO reduced at 260 °C, 300 °C, 350 °C and 400 °C, respectively. Thus, as the reduction temperature increases, the nickel crystal sizes get larger. For the catalysts with 5%Mn, no characteristic peaks of MnO were present in the XRD patterns when they were reduced below 350 °C. This shows that the manganese species are well dispersed in the catalysts and their crystallite sizes are below the detection limit of XRD [35]. When the reduction temperature is 400 °C or higher, the characteristic peaks of Mn start to appear, which are signed to MnO (JCPDS data No. 07-0230), even though the amount of Mn was the same. For Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalysts reduced at 500 °C (Fig. S1), MnO peaks were sharper and crystalline peaks of the sample matched well with the XRD card, indicating the growth of MnO crystallines at 500 °C. Meanwhile, for the XRD patterns of the catalyst reduced at 500 °C, peaks at 51.3° for metallic nickel disappeared, and the sharpest peaks at 43.4° were coincident to the JCPDS data No. 47-1019 for the Ni-Zn alloy. Thus, the Ni-Zn alloy was formed when the catalyst was reduced at higher temperature. The loading manner of Mn can also affect its phase in the catalyst, as well as the crystal size. Fig. 1d shows the XRD patterns of three types of Mn-doped catalysts under the same calcination and reduction conditions: MNZ prepared by co-precipitation; MNZ-1 prepared by Ni impregnation on the co-precipitated MnOx-ZnO; MNZ-2 prepared by Ni and Mn co-impregnation on the synthesized ZnO. The co-precipitated catalysts show no characteristic peaks of MnOx for MNZ and MNZ-1 reduced at 350 °C, due to the high dispersion of Mn in the catalysts. However, for the impregnated catalysts, Mn is exposed on the surface and the characteristic peaks of MnOx appeared for the MNZ-2 catalyst. Therefore, only when prepared by co-precipitation with other metals in the synthesis, Mn can disperse well in the catalyst, leading to very weak or disappearing diffraction peaks of MnOx. The broadening of the characteristic peaks at 2θ = 43–44° of nickel indicates smaller Ni crystal sizes in the MNZ and MNZ-1 catalysts [44]. For the MNZ-2 catalyst, the characteristic peaks of nickel species are sharper, indicating the larger crystal sizes. Fig. 2 shows Ni 2p XPS spectra for 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO and Ni/ZnO reduced at 350 °C. The binding energies of the main peaks are nearly identical to those of oxidized nickel (2p3/2 = 855.2 eV and 872.9 eV). However, the presence of a shoulder peak at lower energy at 852.5 eV in both spectra indicates the further existence of metallic nickel. The shoulder peak is more pronounced for the Ni/ZnO catalysts, demonstrating a higher reduction extent for Ni/ZnO than for 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO under the same condition [34,45]. For the 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalysts, the reduction temperature affects the amount of reduced Ni in the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 3 a. The catalyst reduced at a higher temperature exhibits a more pronounced shoulder peak, indicating a higher level of reduction to Ni° in the catalyst. When the reduction temperature exceeds 500 °C, metallic nickel dominates with the Ni 2p peak shifted from 852.5 eV to 851.7 eV, attributed to the interaction of Ni with Zn, consistent with the observation of Ni-Zn alloys from the XRD results for MNZ-500 in Fig. S2. Mn 2p spectra for the 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalysts obtained before and after the reduction are presented in Fig. 3b. As Mn has many possible oxidation states, such as Mn(VII), Mn(VI), Mn(IV), Mn(III), Mn(II), and Mn, although Mn(II) nitrates was employed in the catalyst preparation, the Mn species can be oxidized to higher oxidation states after deposition and calcination at high temperature in the air. This is reflected by the very broad Mn 2p peaks for the catalysts before the reduction (MNZ-00) [46]. After the reduction, especially upon reduction at the high temperature (500 °C), the Mn species with high oxidation state were reduced to Mn(II) by forming MnO on the surface of the catalyst (Fig. S2), resulting in narrower Mn peak for the catalyst after the reduction. Fig. 4 presents the TPR profiles for the Ni-ZnO and Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalysts. Both catalysts exhibit a main reduction peak at ∼370 °C, ascribed to the reduction of NiO to metallic Ni. For the 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalysts, there is also a weak feature at 150 °C, attributed to the reduction of surface Mn species in higher oxidation states (Mn(VII) or Mn(VI)). The initial temperature for the Ni feature is 230 °C for Ni/ZnO, 50 °C lower than that for 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO, although they end at the same temperature, indicating the higher interaction of nickel with the support in 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalysts. The narrower peak for Mn-promoted catalysts suggests the specific interaction between Ni and the promoter, as well as the better dispersion of nickel on 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO. These results are consistent with the XPS results shown in Fig. 2 in that nickel on Ni-ZnO is better reduced at 350 °C than that on 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO. Morphologies of the representative catalysts were illustrated in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5a–c shows the TEM patterns of the catalysts 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO, Ni/ZnO and Ni/MnOx. And Fig. 5d–f display the corresponding HRTEM images. The average particle size of 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO, Ni/ZnO and Ni/MnOx was 10.8, 17.8 and 38.8 nm, respectively (Fig. 5g–i). The 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalyst was found to have a more uniform dispersion of the metal with nanoparticles of about 10 nm in diameter, and as shown in Fig. 5d the crystalline was formed based on the clear lattice fringes. When the catalyst support is ZnO or MnOx, the particle size is larger than that of 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO. As shown in Fig. 5e, the nickel particles on the catalysts are visible from the passive film on the nickel surface based on two different directions of the lattice fringes in one particle. For Ni/MnOx (Fig. 5c and f), the support is 30–50 nm in size and nickel on the support is well dispersed and is 5 nm in diameter. The TEM results of these catalysts indicate that the addition of Mn results in enhanced dispersion of Ni on the catalyst, consistent with our XRD results. The evolution of the composites of the three metal oxides is illustrated in Figs. 6–8 by the EDX mapping of the metal elements for 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO before the reduction, reduced at 350 °C and 500 °C, respectively. Because the catalyst was prepared by co-precipitation, the EDX mappings of the three metals (Ni, Mn, Zn) show a homogeneous distribution before the reduction, and the weak signals of Mn in Fig. 6 is due to its small amount (5%) in the catalyst. When the catalysts were reduced at 350 °C, metallic Ni was formed and detected on the ZnO surface. Fig. 7 shows that these nickel nanoparticles have an average diameter of 10 nm. After the reduction, the Mn signal got stronger, although Mn remained well dispersed. Increasing the reduction temperature to 500 °C, the EDX mappings of Ni and Zn display the similar heterogeneous distribution, and larger particles in diameter of 100–200 nm are present in Fig. 8b and c, resulting from the Ni-Zn alloys due to the strong interaction between Ni and Zn, as also confirmed by the XRD patterns (Fig. S2). However, the EDX mapping of Mn in Fig. 8d shows pronounced signals at specific places, which are assigned to MnO aggregated on the catalyst surface. These specific spots on the catalysts have the similar elemental distribution found from the overall mapping images as shown in Figs. S3–S5 and Tables S2–S4. In particular, from Fig. S5 and Table S4, spot 2 and spot 4 have the comparable Ni to Zn atomic ratio, indicating that the two spots are in the Ni-Zn alloy region. Spot 3 is the aggregated MnO region on the catalyst surface, where more than 90% of the detected metal element is Mn. In Fig. 8d, the MnO region was also observed, where the Mn signal is the most pronounced, consistent with the XRD patterns in Fig. S2, suggesting that the high reduction temperature leads to the phase separation of manganese from the mixture. From the distribution of manganese in the three reduction stages, it was found that as the reduction temperature increases, more oxidized manganese in high oxidation states was reduced, separated from the mixture, and aggregated on the catalyst surface. From the characterizations it can be concluded that the high dispersion of Mn plays an important role on the promotion to the structure of the catalyst. The proper level of Mn loading prevents the growth of the nickel particles, resulting in smaller particle sizes than Ni/ZnO (Fig. 5). However, the amount of Mn must match that of Ni for optimal dispersion of the nickel on the support, whereas overloaded Mn tends to segregate and cover the active sites on the catalyst surface. Moreover, the way to introduce the Mn promoter into the catalyst also matters, and co-precipitation is preferable leading to homogenous distribution of Mn in the catalyst. When Mn is present in the catalyst, the reduction temperature of the catalyst also affects its structure. Higher reduction temperature leads to the separation of Mn from the catalyst, whereas the opposite reduces the extent in reducing nickel oxide into metallic nickel, and the latter is the active species for the hydrogenation. Thus, an optimal reduction temperature and the proper Mn loading, along with the coprecipitation method, result in high dispersion of Mn and uniform Ni nanoparticles on the support. Furthermore, the higher activation temperature for Ni reduction profile in H2-TPR (Fig.4) pattern indicates the higher interaction of Ni with the support. Meanwhile, the shoulder peak of Ni 2p XPS at the lower energy of 852 eV for 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalyst in Fig. 2 is weaker than that for Ni/ZnO catalyst after reduction under the same condition, suggesting the lower reduction extent of the Mn-doped catalyst. As such, nickel over 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalyst could be reduced in slower rate compared to that on Ni/ZnO, and it is natural that the more uniform nanoparticle can be observed on 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalyst in the TEM pattern (Fig. 5). Thus, it can be concluded that the Mn could not only favor the dispersion of nickel crystal but also the particle uniformity of the catalyst. 3.3 Performance of Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO for microalgae conversion The catalytic activities of our catalysts were tested for microalgae (Chlorococcum sp.) conversion under hydrothermal conditions in a hydrogen-rich atmosphere. Polyols, including 1,2-PDO, EG, glycerol and 1,2-BDO, are the main liquid products, accounting for 60–70%. The remained carbon in the raw materials was converted into gaseous products (yield of 5–10%, including CO2, CH4 and CO) and solid products (yield of 20–25%). Fig. 9 presents the distribution of the liquid products using the Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO, Ni-MnOx and Ni-ZnO catalysts. The highest yield of the main products (1,2-PDO, EG, glycerol and 1,2-BDO) reaches 53.6% over Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalysts, and the CTL is up to 66.9%. When the catalyst support is merely ZnO or MnOx, the yield of the main product dropped to 43.1% and 35.4%. The conversion of the solid carbon to liquid in the raw materials over Ni-ZnO and Ni-MnOx also decreases to 62.0% and 64.8%, respectively. Table 2 summarizes the performance of the catalysts with different Mn loadings, reduced at different temperatures, and prepared by different methods. 1,2-PDO, EG, glycerol and 1,2-BDO are the major liquid products. As listed in Table 2 entry 1–5, the catalyst promoted by 5% Mn has the highest catalytic performance with a yield of 53.6% for the main products and the CTL of 66.9%. For the catalyst with 1% Mn loading, the yield of the main products is 50.0% with the CTL of 65.3%. With the higher Mn loading of 10%, the CTL is 65.7% and the yield of the main products drops to 46.5%. From the XRD patterns of catalysts promoted with different Mn content (Fig. 1a), 5% of Mn is a critical point for the appearance of MnO when the catalysts were reduced at 350 °C. An excessive amount of Mn results in pure MnO crystalline covering on the catalyst surface and burying some of active sites, leading to reduced catalytic activity. When the amount of Mn is fixed, the variation of the reduction temperature can also affect the catalytic activity. From entry 5–6 of Table 2, the catalysts reduced at the lower temperatures of 240 °C and 300 °C have excellent catalytic activity and yields of the major products are both up to 50%. When the reduction temperature is raised to 400 °C, the resulting catalyst has lower catalytic activity than that reduced at 350 °C. Further increasing the reduction temperature to 500 °C, the catalytic activity dropped dramatically, and the yield of 1,2-PDO is only 8.5% with no EG detected. Thus, for catalysts reduced at different temperatures, the higher reduction temperature leads to much lower catalytic activity. In general, the active sites for the hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis are Ni° or Ni+ and the higher reduction temperature may generate more Ni°. However, in our work, when the catalysts were reduced at 500 °C, which is used in the literature [10,13,15], although more Ni° was generated, the catalytic activity was unsatisfying. From the EDS mapping and XRD patterns of the catalysts, we found that most of nickel in the catalysts reduced at 500 °C formed the Ni-Zn alloy as observed from the XRD patterns (Fig. S2). In contrast, catalysts reduced at 350 °C had more nickel nanoparticles, which were likely the catalytic active sites. From entry 9–10 of Table 2, the preparing method was also found to greatly affect the catalytic performance. Catalysts prepared by impreanation show poor catalytic activity; the yield of the major products is less than 15% and the conversion of the solid carbon to liquid products is only ∼50%.The decrease in the catalytic activity of MNZ-1 and MNZ-2 is due to the larger crystal size of nickel in these catalysts and the excess MnO on the catalyst surface. Therefore, for microalgae hydrolytic hydrogenation, the co-precipitated Mn/Ni/ZnO catalysts with 5% Mn addition reduced at 350 °C have the best catalytic performance. 3.4 Mn promotion effects on the conversion of microalgae In previous works, 1,2-PDO and EG were derived from carbohydrates in microalgae, which were hydrolyzed from microalgae by a dissociative proton from water at high temperature [25,47,48]. Thus, the reaction pathway for the conversion of microalgae to 1,2-PDO and EG was proposed with glucose as the substrate over the Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalyst. Based on the existing literature [14–16,49,50], we proposed the pathway as shown in Scheme 1 , which includes three processes: 1) retro-aldol + hydrogenation; 2) dehydration + hydrogenation; 3) isomerization + retro-aldol + hydrogenation. In the first process, glycoaldehyde is formed via CC bond cleavage in glucose, followed by hydrogenation to form EG. The second path involves dehydration of glucose to form methyglyoxal, and the subsequent hydrogenation of methyglyoxal to acetol and then to 1,2-PDO. In the third path, glycerol is first formed by isomerization of glucose to fructose, followed by the retro-aldol reaction to yield 1,3-dihydroxyacetone and the further hydrogenation, and the resulting glycerol is then converted into 1,2-PDO, EG, as well as other aliphatic alcohols such methanol through hydrogenolysis. Table 3 shows the catalytic performance of glucose and other possible intermediates in our microalgae hydrogenation. When the substrate is glucose, increasing the reaction time from 1.0 h to 3.0 h leads to the increase in the yield of 1,2-PDO from 30.8% to 39.8%, although the yield of glycerol drops from 18.7% to 8.3% with that of EG essentially unchanged (Table 3, entry 1–3). As the increase in the amount of 1,2-PDO is almost equal to the decrease in that of glycerol, some 1,2-PDO is likely to derive from glycerol. To validate our first pathway, glycoaldehyde was used as the substrate and the main product was found to be EG, accounting for more than 50% of the conversion (Table 3, entry 4–5). We proposed that 1,2-PDO was produced through the second and the third processes, where methylglyoxal and acetol are the intermediate products in the second pathway, and fructose, 1,3-dihydroxyacetone and glycerol are those in the third pathway. Treating these intermediate products in the hydrogen atmosphere over the Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalyst, the dominant products were found to be 1,2-PDO, especially for methyglyoxal and acetol. From entry 6 and 7 of Table 3, methyglyoxal can be converted into 1,2-PDO with yields of 67.7% and 66.0%, and the reaction is completed within 1.0 h. Acetol, the hydrogenation product of methylglyoxal, can be also converted into 1,2-PDO within 1.0 h (entry 8). From entry 9–15 of Table 3, the yields of 1,2-PDO from fructose, 1,3-dihydroxyacetone and glycerol are 50.9%, 53.0% and 62.2%, respectively, after of the reaction for 3.0 h. When the reaction time is reduced to 2.0 h, the yield of 1,2-PDO decreases by 8.0%, and the conversion of glycerol is also reduced. In 1.0 h, the conversion of glycerol dropped dramatically and was only 22.8%. This suggests that the hydroganolysis process is slower than the isomerization and hydrogenation reactions, so the former is likely the rate determining step. In the catalytic reaction system, microalgae were hydrolyzed and monose (glucose) was released first, which was then converted into C2 and C3 alcohols through hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis. Strictly speaking, hydrogenation in organic chemistry refers to the process of adding H atoms to unsaturated bonds, such as CC or other unsaturated groups, while hydrogenolysis is the process by replacing a group or atom, such as OH or CH3, with an H atom [51,52]. Thus CC bond cleavages of the retro-aldol reaction and dehydroxylation of glycerol belong to hydrogenolysis. In this work, the released glucose is subjected to the retro-aldol reaction, and is converted into the intermediate products and then alcohols through hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis. The equilibrium among the hydrolysis of microalgae, the hydrogenolysis of glucose and the hydrogenation of the intermediate products determines the product distribution, where the active sites on the catalyst play the essential role. Therefore, bifunctional catalysts are needed in this reaction. In this work, our Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalysts were found to have superior catalytic activity for the formation of glycols from the carbohydrates in microalgae compared with other nickel-based catalysts. Thus, addition of the Mn promoter significantly improved the performance of the Ni-ZnO catalysts. To further illustrate the promotional effects of Mn in our catalysts, comparison of Mn/Ni/ZnO with Ni/ZnO for catalyzing the hydrogenation of the intermediate products were made to determine the effect of the Mn promotion as shown in Table 4 . For entry 1 and 2, glycoaldehyde is subjected to the hydrogenation process and the yield of EG over Ni/ZnO is slightly higher than that over Mn/Ni/ZnO. Similarly, when the substrates are methyglyoxal and acetol, the yields of 1,2-PDO are comparable over Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO and Ni/ZnO catalysts (entry 3–6). As the above reactions are only hydrogenation, we conclude that the Mn promoter does not significantly affect the hydrogenation process. For glycerol conversion to 1,2-PDO, which is a typical hydrogenolysis process, higher yield of 1,2-PDO and higher conversion of glycerol were found over Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalysts (entry 11 and 12). In addition, the conversion of fructose and 1,3-dihydroxyacetone to 1,2-PDO also includes hydrogenolysis such as the retro-aldol reaction of fructose and glycerol dehydroxylation, and in entry 7–10, with fructose and 1,3-dihydroxyacetone as the substrates, the yield of 1,2-PDO is considerably higher over Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalysts than over Ni/ZnO. These results suggest that the Mn component in our catalysts mainly promote the hydrogenolysis process but not the hydrogenation step. In biomass conversion, Ni is one of the most frequently used metals for the hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehyde due to its activity for hydrogen adsorption [53–57]. Thus, there is no question that nickel plays the key role for hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis in our reaction. The ZnO support is not only used to disperse and stabilize the metal active sites, but also provides the acid-base sites to enhance the CC cleavage and the dehydroxylation processes [25]. By comparing the ZnO supported nickel catalyst with neutral Active Carbon (AC) supported nickel catalyst in Table S5, it can be seen that 20.0% sorbitol was obtained in glucose hydrogenation over catalyst with neutral support AC while no sorbitol was observed after 3.0 h hydrogenation of glucose over Ni/ZnO and 5%Mn/Ni/ZnO catalysts, demonstrating the good ability of the ZnO support to break CC bonds. In general, other transition metals were also introduced to adjust the properties of the support in order to further enhance the catalytic activity [26–30,58]. It has been reported that the addition of Fe and Re to the catalysts substantially boosts the deoxygenation and C–O hydrogenolysis activity, resulting in the complete deoxygenation of guaiacol to cyclohexane [29]. The basic nature of the support is known to be responsible for glucose isomerization to fructose followed by the retro-aldol reaction [16,59], and the support ZnO used in our study has both acidity and basicity. The addition of Mn also adjusts the acidity of the support. As shown in Fig. S6, the amount of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites are both enhanced in the Mn-promoted ZnO catalyst, which are also quantified in Table S6. According to the proposed reaction pathways in Scheme 1, glycerol is formed as an intermediate via isomerization of glucose to fructose followed by the retro-aldol reaction to dihydroxyacetone, which is then hydrogenated to glycerol to produce 1,2-PDO from C–O hydroangenolysis of glycerol. The yield of 1,2-PDO increases when fructose, dihydroxyacetone and glycerol are the substrates over Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalyst compared with Ni-ZnO catalyst. Lewis acid was reported to favor the isomerization of glucose and CC bond cleavage [60–64], as well as the yield of 1,2-PDO is twice over Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO than that over Ni-ZnO in this work. Thus, the CC and C–O bond breakages are also promoted by the Mn dopants in the synthesized catalysts. Thus, the addition of Mn not only promotes the dispersion of nickel on the catalyst but also enhances the hydrogenolysis reaction, including the CC bond cleavage in the retro-aldol reaction and glycerol dehydroxylation. However, as the Ni/ZnO and Mn/Ni/ZnO catalysts have comparable catalytic activity in the hydrogenation process, this process is not sensitive to the size of nickel particles or the acidity of the support. Thus, the promotion effect of Mn was mainly shown in the hydrogenolysis process, largely due to the improved dispersion and reduced particle size of Ni, as well as the increase in the Lewis acid sites of support. 4 Conclusions In summary, Mn-promoted Ni-based catalysts prepared at mild reduction temperature were shown to have high performance towards microalgae hydrolytic hydrogenation. The catalytic activity of our synthesized catalyst depended largely on the amount of the Mn added, the reduction temperature and the preparation method (impregnation or co-precipitation). The catalyst prepared by co-precipitation with 5% Mn and reduced at 350 °C exhibited the best performance, where the total yield of 1,2-PDO, EG, glycerol and 1,2-BDO reached 53.6% in the direct hydrogenation of microalgae. The addition of a proper amount of Mn into the Ni-ZnO catalyst was found to greatly enhance the dispersion of Ni and the formation of small Ni nanoparticles, which acted as the active sites in the hydrogenation reaction. The Mn-promoted Ni-ZnO catalyst was superior to the un-promoted catalyst for the dehydroxylation as well as the CC bond cleavage due to the increasing number of Lewis acid sites. Our findings not only provide a promising route for efficient biomass upgrading, but also shed light on the development of efficient and stable bimetallic nanocatalysts for hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Mn-promoted nickel-based catalysts were explored for the direct hydrogenation of microalgae (Chlorococcum sp.) containing 49.6% of carbohydrates in water. With this catalyst at 250 °C for 3.0 h, microalgae was completely decomposed, where the conversion of microalgae to liquid products (CTL) and the total yield of polyols reached 66.9%, and 53.6%, respectively. Among polyols, the total yield of 1,2-propanediol and ethylene glycol were 41.7%. XRD, XPS and TEM-EDX characterizations showed that 5% of Mn addition, 350 °C of reduction temperature and the co-precipitation synthesis ensured the excellent dispersion of the Ni catalyst with small particle sizes. The Mn promoter was found to stabilize the catalyst structure by preventing the Ni particles from aggregation and to effectively promote retro-aldol and dehydroxylation reaction due to the increasing number of Lewis acid sites. Meanwhile, the hydrogenation pathways over nickel-based catalysts were proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Mn-promoted hydrogenation of microalgae (Chlorococcum sp.) to 1,2-propanediol and ethylene glycol over Ni-ZnO catalysts
